PZVVa7sR.title: Implicit and explicit memory in the patient with amnestic mild cognitive impairment
PZVVa7sR.abstract: BACKGROUND: Patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (MCI) were considered to be going to develop into Alzheimer disease, and were the high-risk group of Alzheimer disease. OBJECTIVE: To study the implicit and explicit memory in the patient with amnestic MCI. DESIGN: Homochronous and controlled observation. SETTING: Neurological Department of the Southern Building of General Hospital of Chinese PLA. PARTICIPANTS: The research was carried out at Neurological Department of the Southern Building of General Hospital of Chinese PLA from January to June 2003. Totally 20 male patients with amnestic mild MCI, with the average age of (78.7±4.9) years and the average educational time of (8.2±1.0) years, selected from neurological out-patient clinic and ward of southern building of General Hospital of Chinese PLA, Complaint memory losing and confirmed by the relatives and close friends of the patients, Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) ≥24, activity of daily living (ADL) <26, and clinical dementia rating equal to 0.5, Objective memory examination score reduced compared to the examiners' educational background, the memory quotient recorded by clinical memory sheet to be 63-77 (lower than the normal value with 1.5-2.5 standard deviation), were accepted, and determined as experiment group.Totally 20 healthy male veterans selected from Beijing area, with the average age of (77.9±4.7) years and the average educational time (8.1±1.1) years were selected as control group. All subjects volunteered to take part in the examination. METHODS: Explicit memory included word free recall and re-recognition task. The Chinese characters were selected from the 1000 most commonly used ones in the books of primary and middle schools. The 30 double characters-words were chosen and randomly divided into two tasks. Recall task included 10 double character words that were target words. Re-recognition task included 20 double character words, of which one half were target words, and the other half were interfering words. Implicit memory included word free recall and character-root-complementary task. The Chinese characters were from the same source as mentioned before. Thirty Chinese characters were chosen in free recall task at beginning. These Chinese characters at least had possibility of composing over 4 commonly used double character-words in primary and middle school books. One double-Chinese character-word in four possibilities was randomly selected and the total was 30 words. Then these 30 words were divided into two groups, one was target group and the other was interfering word. All selected Chinese characters were composed either up-down structure or right-left structure. Taking a part of the Chinese character would leave a character-root. There were 30 character-roots and they were never the same each other. There were at least four possibilities to form a Chinese character for each root as properly matching among 1000 commonly used Chinese characters. At first, the subjects were asked to read the target words loudly for 3 times in 4 tasks and tried to remember all the target words (characters) and were told to test their memorization later on. The target words (or characters) would appear in one-minute interval. The subjects were asked to repeat the words (or characters) appeared before as many as possible based on their memory in free recall task and they did not have to remember the words (or characters) in order. The correct recall rate for 10 target words was calculated. In re-recognition task, the target words and interfering words were mixed up and appeared one by one in random order and the subjects were asked to tell if the words appeared before. The correct rate of 20-word re-recognition was calculated. In free recall task, the first character in target words was mixed with the first character in interfering words and they appeared one by one in random order. The subjects were asked to form any two-character-word with appeared Chinese characters and wrote down the first word thought of in test sheet. The hitting rate of target words and interfering words were calculated. t-test for independent samples was carried out respectively between the two groups. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: ① Semantic priming effect (the hitting rate of target words in word free recall task and the hitting rate of interfering words) and apperception priming effect (the hitting rate of target words in character-root-complementary task and the hitting rate of interfering words) in the two groups. ② Difference of explicit memory (correct rate of free recall and correct rate of re-recognition) and difference of semantic and apperception priming effect in the two groups. RESULTS: All subjects in the two groups completed the test and entered the final analysis. ① Results of inner-group analysis: In the group of MCI, the hitting rate (0.41±0.15) of target words in word free recall task was significantly higher than that of interfering words (0.31±0.12, P < 0.01), suggesting that there existed semantic priming effect in the patients with amnestic MCI as completing this task. In the character-root-complementary task, the hitting rate of target words (0.17±0.10) was significantly higher than that of the hitting rate of interfering words (0.10±0.07, P < 0.05), suggesting that there existed perceptional priming effect in the patients with amnestic MCI as completing this task. In the control group, the hitting rate of target words (0.45±0.11) was significantly higher than that of the interfering words (0.33±0.10, P < 0.01), suggesting that there existed semantic priming effect in the elderly with normal perception as completing this task as well. In the character-root-complementary task, the hitting rate of target characters (0.18±0.08) was higher than that of interfering characters (0.13±0.07, P < 0.05), suggesting that there existed perceptional priming effect in the elderly with normal perception as completing this task as well. ② Results of inter-groups analysis: Correct rates of free recall and re-recognition in the MCI group was decreased (0.10±0.09, 0.45±0.13, t=9.858, P=0.000; 0.69±0.14, 0.83±0.08, t=3.685, P=0.000). There was not significantly different in Sementic priming effect and perceptional priming effect both in the MCI group and the control group. CONCLUSION: Sementic priming effect and perceptional priming effect were existed both in the MCI experiment group and the control group, but the implicit memory was not significantly different in the two groups. However, the patients with forgetful style MCI were exhibited a decline in explicit memory. Memory function of mild MCI patients was shown double characteristics, i.e. damage of explicit memory and preservation of implicit memory. The double character in memorial function provided theoretical basis for the rehabilitative training of MCI patients.

2UVDWyNr.title: A nimodipine interventional study of patients with mild cognitive impairment]
2UVDWyNr.abstract: To observe the effect of nimodipine on the cognition status and the changes of metabolites in brain tissue in the patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in order to evaluate the significance of intervening MCI with medication.31 patients with MCI were selected 16 cases were in a treatment group taking nimodipine for 3 months besides taking basic internal medication and 15 cases in a control group taking only basic internal medication. Before and after treatment, multiple cognition tests were carried out in both groups and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) in Hippocampus region was carried out in 5 patients of the treatment group.Verbal instant recall scores, symbol digit modalities test (SDMT) scores and mini-mental state examination (MMSE) total scores in the treatment group were improved significantly after treatment as compared with those in the control group (P < 0.05).Nimodipine can improve memory ability as well as attention ability of the patients with MCI to a certain extent and make the general cognition function improved.

dKekl6ot.title: Survey of diagnosis and therapy in the Parkinson's disease
dKekl6ot.abstract: Objective To investigate the status of diagnosis and therapy on Parkinson’s disease. Methods The questionnaire survey of PD was conducted in 2006. 80 PD patients were randomly selected from the clinics of General Hospital of Chinese PLA materials in data. Bank was established and analysed with SPSS software. Results Only 3.75% of patients were aware of possibly having PD at onset. 53.75% of patients were diagnosed as PD 1 year after onset. The most frequently used drug was madopar. Artane and amantadine were commonly used in our country. The most common approaches included single use of madopar and artane + amantadine in the earlier period of disease. After four or five years,the most common approaches included single use of madopar and madopar +artane + amantadine. The clinical improvement was about 77.2 % in assessment of modified Webster's scale.About 13.75% of patients did not follow the prescription and failed to take medicine. 20% and 32.5% of patients didn't know how to arrange diet and exercise scientifically. Conclusions Doctors and patients should know more knowledge of Parkinson's disease.

WtMMvq02.title: A cross-sectional study of neurological disease in the veterans of military communities in Beijing]
WtMMvq02.abstract: To investigate the prevalence of cognitive and motor disorders as well as emotional and sleep abnormality in the veterans from military communities in Beijing.The participants underwent a comprehensive in-person evaluation including detailed neuropsychological testing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale and special questionnaires for movement and sleep disorders.The overall prevalence of cognitive impairment, extrapyramidal diseases was 32.7%, 8.8%. The prevalence of mild cognitive impairment, dementia, Parkinson disease, essential tremor, anxiety and depression was 26.2%, 6.5%, 2.0%, 6.1%, 1.4% and 4.1% respectively. Prevalence of all kinds of sleep disorders ranged from 10.3% to 53.9%. The prevalence of cognitive impairment had no significant difference of sex, but were correlated to age and education, the correlation coefficient was 0.326 and -0.221 (P<0.01).Veterans from military communities had higher prevalence of cognitive impairment, extrapyramidal diseases and sleep disorders and lower that of anxiety and depression relatively.

GSUGvc0R.title: Analysis of related influencing factors for dementia in Parkinson disease
GSUGvc0R.abstract: Objective To investigate the related influencing factors of Parkinson disease dementia (PDD).Methods A controlled study was conducted in Outpatient Department of Parkinson disease from 2006 to 2007.There were 48 PDD patients (PDD group) and 72 Parkinson disease (PD) patients (PD group).In PDD patients,dementia was found at least 2 or more than 2 years after occurrence of PD. Questionnaire,including baseline information was performed.The grade of PD was diagnosed in accordance with "UK Parkinson Disease Society Brain Bank Clinical Diagnostic Criteria".Dementia diagnosis was based on "Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders Forth Edition(DSM-Ⅳ)". PD was evaluated by Unified Parkinson Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS).Cognitive condition was assessed by Mini-Mental State Examination(MMSE),Montreal Cognitive Assessment(MoCA),Rapid Verbal Retrieve Test (RVR) and Clock Drawing Test (CDT).Single unconditioned logistic regression analysis and multiple logistic regression model were applied.Results The mean age was (75.44±8.97) years old in PDD group and (70.35±11.34) years old in PD group.In simple factor analysis,age and UPDRS Ⅲ score in PDD group were all higher than those in PD group (P<0.05,for all).The probability of dementia in tremor type PD was comparably lower (OR=0.364,95%CI:0.139-0.953).Depression was found to be a high risk factor for PDD (OR=2.647,95% CI:0.963-7.000).Multivariate analysis showed that age,educational degree,UPDRS Ⅲ score and tremor type were factors entered in regression equation (OR=1.203,0.790, 4.264,0.065,respectively).Conclusion Age,educational degree,UPDRS Ⅲ score,tremor type and depression are the related influencing factors for PDD.

1ItWeh4p.title: Several novel indicators being applied to analyze the relationships between Chinese economic growth, energy consumption and its impact of emissions
1ItWeh4p.abstract: The sustainability of Chinese economy has attracted attentions from all over the world since China's reform & opening up policy. This paper attempted to evaluate the relationships among Chinese economy, energy and its impact of emissions during 1991-2009 using several novel indicators based on emergy, energy and monetary units. The results show that NH 3-N in wastewater has taken main responsibility for impact of emissions, the hidden environmental cost per unit economic output has been continuously reduced, education and R & D investment has cut pollutants generating intensity since 1997, and environmental protection investment has cut emission intensity since 1996. Generally speaking, the coordination degree of structure and scale of China's economy has been improved to different degree from 1991 to 2009. However, the growth of education and R & D investment and environmental protection investment has not prevented impact of emissions from increase caused by economic aggregate growth, and the turning point has not appeared in this period. Finally, this paper discusses some related issues and puts forward the corresponding suggestions. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

tkJ9KLYF.title: EFFECTS OF BIOGAS SLURRY ON YIELD AND QUALITY OF OIL-SEED RAPE
tkJ9KLYF.abstract: Biogas slurry is a good source of plant nutrients and replacing chemical fertilizers with biogas slurry can not only achieve resource utilization of slurry, but also reduce the amount of fertilizer. In this study, biogas slurry was applied in the production of oil-seed rape, it was attempted to investigate the effects of slurry on yield and quality of rape, furthermore to find the optimum rate of biogas slurry. The results showed that the protein, iron (Fe), manganese (Mn), copper (Cu), and zinc (Zn) contents in rapeseed increased, the oleic acid, calcium (Ca) and magnesium (Mg) contents in rapeseed firstly increased and then decreased with the increased rate of slurry. Meanwhile, the erucic acid, glucosinolate and oil contents showed a tendency of decrease with the increased rate of slurry. When the rate of slurry was in the range of 78,750 kg hm-2 to 101,250 kg hm-2, the yield reached a relatively high level, which was in the range of 2817kg hm-2 to 3433 kg hm-2. © 2013 Copyright Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.

t0yQcbkz.title: Emergy evaluation of the sustainability of Chinese steel production during 1998–2004
t0yQcbkz.abstract: This paper deals with the application of eMergy analysis to the sustainability of Chinese steel production in 1998–2004. Emissions' impacts were quantified using eMergy synthesis and other methods (dilution method, disability adjusted life years (DALY) method and ecological cumulative exergy consumption (ECEC) method). The results show that its sustainability is very low and declining in this period, emissions obviously reduce the sustainability although their impacts are generally decreasing, and the main reasons lie in its low nonrenewable resources and energies' efficiencies. Finally, the related suggestions were put forward for improving its comprehensive performance.

AVLoIVOp.title: A sustainability analysis of a municipal sewage treatment ecosystem based on emergy
AVLoIVOp.abstract: “Discharge of treated wastewater and sewage sludge landfilling” are the most common practice, which poses threats to the local environment. In this work we first constructed a general sewage treatment ecosystem (STE) which integrated the three systems. Emergy synthesis, with several improved emergy-based indicators which considered the waste input contribution and impacts of emissions, was applied to evaluate two alternative scenarios (scenario 1: sewage treatment system + treated water discharge + sludge landfilling; scenario 2: sewage treatment subsystem + reclaimed water reuse subsystem + aerobic compost production subsystem) for Mingjingtan sewage treatment plant in Wanzhou City of Chongqing in China. Results point out the environmental pressure of scenario 2 is much smaller than scenario 1 although its economic performance is somewhat poorer than scenario 1, and finally the sustainability of scenario 2 is still much better than scenario 1. Therefore, the treated water and sewage sludge reuse can further improve the environmental benefit of the sewage treatment process; however, the STE should be optimized in order to enhance its economic benefit. The proposed methods can help policy-makers make decisions and guide designers and operators to improve the comprehensive performance of sewage treatment processes. In addition, this paper also briefly discusses wastewater integrated management strategy. Keywords Sewage treatment ecosystem Emergy based indicator Reclaimed water Sludge Sustainability 1 Introduction Municipal sewage treatment plants play an important role in the abatement of water pollution, but they also produce a large amount of sewage sludge and treated water. The discharge of large volumes of treated wastewater that contains low levels of chemical constituents may still lead to an excessive input of nutrients in a receiving water body ( Muga and Mihelcic, 2008 ). In 2008, the total wastewater discharge amount in China was 57.17 billion tons, 57.7% of which came from municipal domestic sewage; the total discharge amount of chemical oxygen demand (COD) was 13.21 million tons, 65.4% of which came from municipal domestic sewage; the total discharge amount of ammonia nitrogen (NH 3 -N) was 1.27 million tons, 76.6% of which came from municipal domestic sewage ( Institute of Public & Environmental Affairs, 2009 ). The main rivers were polluted to varying degrees and eutrophication that occurred in the main lakes (reservoirs) was serious in China this year ( Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China, 2009 ). Groundwater of nearly 90% of Chinese cities has been polluted to different degrees. However, per capita water supply in China is about one fourth of the world average level, and water pollution may be mainly responsible for the water scarcity of 136 cities in China. In many cases, managing sewage sludge consists of collection followed by disposal, usually away from urban activity, which could be waterways, open ocean or surface areas demarcated for the purpose, viz. landfills, and landfills may lead to subsurface pollution ( Bresters et al., 1997; Swanson et al., 2004 ). Moreover, with the increased volume and variety of hazardous waste products, the situation becomes more and more a public health concern ( Kollikkathara et al., 2009 ). Most sewage sludge in China is currently disposed into the landfill sites, and this short-sighted practice may lead to exhaustion of the landfill area in a couple of years and therefore is not sustainable ( Cherubini et al., 2008 ). Sixty percent of the world's population will live in urban areas by 2025, and improving urban water and wastewater management in the growing cities of the developing world is an urgent need ( Bahri, 2009 ). The provision of environmentally sound systems in an integrated way, taking into account the whole water cycle of water supply, wastewater, solid waste collection, treatment and reuse, is the best way forward to address this critical challenge ( Bahri, 2009 ). Several methods or amalgamations of some of them have been applied to evaluate wastewater treatment systems in recent years, such as eMergy analysis method ( Björklund et al., 2001; Geber and Björklund, 2002; Nelson et al., 2001; Grönlund et al., 2004; Siracusa and La Rosa, 2006; Chen et al., 2009 ), exergy analysis method ( Hellström and Kärrman, 1997 ), life cycle assessment method ( Ødegaard, 1995; Gallego et al., 2008 ), sustainable process indices (SPI) ( Roggenbauer, 2005 ), amalgamation of several methods (such as LCA and eMergy analysis methods) ( Bengtsson et al., 1997 ), economic evaluation and energy analysis and/or other methods’ amalgamation ( Ko et al., 2004; Muga and Mihelcic, 2008; Hellström and Kärrman, 1997 ). A correct waste management policy should be based on the principles of sustainable development, according to which our refuse is not simply regarded as something to eliminate but rather as a potential resource to be recycled ( Marchettini et al., 2007 ). This requires an integrated waste management evaluation. For this purpose, several methods have been used to assess sewage sludge treatment or management, such as standard energy and LCA analysis methods ( Hara and Mino, 2008 ), economic evaluation ( Yin and Tan, 2005; European Commission DG Environment B/2, 2002 ), etc. Nowadays, wastewater reuse is becoming an economically and environmentally sound method for integrated water management. On the basis of wastewater availability for supplemental applications prior to discharge, water reuse appears to be a suitable practice with potentially beneficial use ( Janosova et al., 2006; Chu et al., 2004; Bahri, 2009 ). Wastewater reuse is an opportunity to shorten the hydrological cycle until the water is used again and can be utilized when it offers sufficient environmental, social, economic and political benefits ( Janosova et al., 2006 ). But this needs to be evaluated specifically for decision-making. At present, some methods have been applied to analyze the performances of reclaimed water reuse, such as economic analysis ( Chu et al., 2004; Janosova et al., 2006 ), economic evaluation method and risk assessment ( Hamilton et al., 2005 ), ecological analysis, standard energy analysis, risk assessment and economic analysis ( Sala and Serra, 2004 ), risk assessment ( Asano and Cotruvo, 2004 ), the sustainable process index (SPI) ( Roggenbauer, 2005 ), etc. All those studies mainly focused on a certain step of the total sewage treatment process, and fewer works focus on its comprehensive performance (including sewage treatment, treated water and sewage sludge disposal). The relationship between a sewage treatment system and its treated water disposal system and sewage sludge disposal system, to some degree, is like a simple ecosystem. Thus we may name the three systems “a sewage treatment ecosystem (STE)”. In an STE, one component can assimilate one or more wastes from another component and make some useful products for human being as far as possible under mankind's control. So the system continuously seeks maximizing the total products by optimizing the resource throughput with the development of science and technology for ensuring that all available resources will be utilized to the maximum possible extent and no unused resources will be left in future ( Ulgiati et al., 2007 ). Meanwhile, for a specific sewage treatment process, designers should not only consider how to make the effluent satisfy environmental discharge limits, but also try their best to find appropriate ways to reuse these by-products under the specific condition. Thus this requires decision-makers and designers take everything into account because resources become scarce and environmental pollution is serious today. An emergy synthesis approach has been applied to evaluate wastewater treatment systems and waste treatment or disposal systems ( Björklund et al., 2001; Geber and Björklund, 2002; Nelson et al., 2001; Grönlund et al., 2004; Siracusa and La Rosa, 2006; Chen et al., 2009; Marchettini et al., 2007; Lei and Wang, 2008; Vassallo et al., 2009 ), but this research has ignored the comprehensive performance of the sewage treatment process. The overall assessment of the wastewater treatment process has begun to be done using LCIAs by some researchers ( Renou et al., 2008 ). It is a good beginning in this respect; however, more emphasis should be given to a natural ecosystem's contributions to a wastewater treatment system and its by-products’ disposal and control of the emissions’ impacts on economy and environment. The goals of this paper are to construct a general sewage treatment ecosystem concept which integrates a wastewater treatment system and its by-products disposal system, then put up the improved eMergy-based indicators for assessing its sustainability. Finally, two scenarios for Mingjingtan sewage treatment plant in Wangzhou City of Chongqing in China, as a case, is applied to validate the proposed indicators. In 2008, the total wastewater discharge amount in Chongqing was 1.45 billion tons, 53.82% of which came from municipal domestic sewage; the total discharge amount of COD was 241.7 thousand tons, 58.13% of which came from municipal domestic sewage; the total discharge amount of NH 3 -N was 23.3 thousand tons, 64.38% of which came from municipal domestic sewage (Institute of Public & Environmental Affairs, 2008). The water pollution in Chongqing is embodied in the Three Gorges Reservoirs’ water pollution. Three Gorges Dam started construction in 1994 and it started impoundment in 2003. Three Gorges Dam leads to the water level of the reservoirs’ water body being raised and reduces its velocity of flow, thus weakens its environmental capacity and self-purification capacity. At present, although its water quality generally meet the requirement for the living and production, water blooms have appeared in some water areas frequently, mainly caused by excessive nitrogen and phosphorus in the water body ( Wei et al., 2009 ). Therefore, this case study can provide beneficial suggestions for the local wastewater integrated management. 2 Research objective Sewage treatment strategies should aim at maximizing energy and material recovery while minimizing the final amount of emissions delivered to environment. These targets should be in conjunction with appropriate technological options that emulate natural cycles and dynamics. Meanwhile, the holistic view from industrial ecology indicates that solving problems must involve understanding the connections that exist between these systems, various aspects cannot be viewed in isolation ( Wikipedia, 2008 ). Therefore, a sewage treatment system and its treated water disposal system and sewage sludge disposal system should form a holistic system, here named a sewage treatment ecosystem (STE). Fig. 1 shows its structures and flows. There are six kinds of flows: the first and the second are the free resources flows and waste flows between environmental system and the STE, respectively; the third and the fourth are the purchased input flows and current flows between economic system and the STE, respectively; the fifth and the sixth are the products flows and current flows between economic system and the STE, respectively. The sewage treatment system provides the sludge disposal system and the treated water disposal system with dewatered sludge and treated water, respectively. Wanzhou district is located on the northeastern brim of Chongqing City in China, lies between longitudes 107°55′22″E and 108°53′25″E and between latitudes 30°24′25″N and 31°14′58″N. Wanzhou lies within the humid semitropical monsoon climate zone, with an average annual temperature of 17.7 °C, an annual average hours of sunshine of 1484.4 h, an annual average precipitation of 1243 mm, and an annual average water surface evaporation 620 mm. Wangzhou City is a mountainous city with rare natural vegetation, currently covers an area of 41 km 2 , and has a total population of 5.95 × 10 5 . Mingjingtan sewage treatment plant is located in the city. This plant adopted the craft of Orbal oxidation ditch (see Fig. 2 ). Its investment was $10,101,250, and it started working in July 2003. The plant has a capacity to treat 30,000 tons sewage per day, and its effluent standard is shown in Table 1 . At present, the treated water is discharged into Yangtze River, the required quality standards for surface water is shown in Table 2 . Its dewatered sludge is disposed in landfills and the landfill leachate is piped into another sewage treatment plant. However, the sewage sludge with high water content (>80%) often makes the landfill site become “a swampland”, which affected the normal operation of the landfill plant, and even shorten its lifetime; meanwhile, too much landfill leachate also affected the effluent quality. As a result, sewage treatment plants refuse to accept the landfill leachate and landfill plants are unwilling to accept sewage sludge. This case will cause many potential and actual environmental problems. Here we considered two scenarios: Scenario 1 – sewage treatment system + treated water discharge + sludge landfilling: this is the present case of Mingjingtan sewage treatment plant. Treated water from the sewage treatment system is discharged into Yangtze River. Scenario 2 – sewage treatment subsystem + reclaimed water reuse subsystem + aerobic compost production subsystem: the three subsystems form a sewage treatment ecosystem. Treated water from the sewage treatment subsystem is deeply treated and then reused for landscape, gardening, etc. According to the research of Shen et al. (2007) , the craft of reclaimed water reuse is shown in Fig. 3 . The water quality standard of reclaimed water reuse in China is shown in Table 3 . Dewatered sludge is used as raw material of aerobic compost production subsystem. Fig. 4 shows the composing craft ( Bai, 2004 ). 3 Methods 3.1 Emergy synthesis approach and the traditional eMergy indicators The emergy synthesis approach is an integrated evaluation method for ecological-economic systems and has been successfully applied to systems of different scales ( Brown and Ulgiati, 2004 ). Emergy (or embodied energy) is defined as the available energy of one kind previously used up directly or indirectly to make a product or service ( Odum, 1996 ). In emergy accounting, both environmental and economic inputs, including energy, materials, labor and currency, are all converted into solar emergy equivalents. The renewable energy and resources, like sunlight, wind, rain, and tides, which are usually regarded as free externalities of the production process in economics, are included in emergy accounting as significant environmental support. An eMergy synthesis considers the historical accumulation of all the energy used in a production process and provides a universal measure for the different kinds of energy flows in a system network. A system is evaluated through the analysis of energy, mass, information, and currency flows ( Sciubba and Ulgiati, 2005; Bastianoni et al., 2007 ). The algorithm for emergy accounting has been given by Odum (1996) . The total annual emergy inflow to the biosphere from the sun, moon, and deep heat sources from the earth make up the baseline. The baseline emergy is the driving force for everything physically happening in the biosphere, together with the storages (e.g. fossil fuels, ores, forest biomass, soil organic content) previously built up by the annual eMergy inflow and used at rates far exceeding their replacement rate. The amount of input eMergy dissipated per unit output exergy is called solar transformity. The latter can be considered a “quality” factor which functions as a measure of the intensity of biosphere support to the product under study. The total solar eMergy of a product may be calculated as: (solar eMergy) = (exergy of the product) × (solar transformity). Solar eMergy is usually measured in solar eMergy joules (seJ), while the unit for solar transformity is solar eMergy joules per joule of product (seJ/J). Sometimes eMergy per unit mass of product or eMergy per unit of currency are also used (seJ/g, seJ/$, etc.). In doing so, all kinds of flows to a system are expressed in the same unit (seJ of solar eMergy) and have a built-in quality factor to account for the conversion of input flows through the biosphere hierarchy. Emergy accounting is organized as a top down approach where first systems diagrams of processes are drawn to organize evaluations and account for all inputs and outflows from the system. Tables of the actual flows of materials, labor, and energy are constructed from the diagrams and all flows are evaluated. The different units for each flow are multiplied by transformities to convert them into solar eMergy. As a result of this procedure, a set of indices and ratios suitable for policymaking ( Brown and Ulgiati, 2004 ) can be calculated. Some indices based on eMergy analysis have been introduced to describe a system and to evaluate the sustainability of a process ( Yang et al., 2003; Zhelev and Ridolfi, 2006; Brown and Ulgiati, 1997; Brown and Ulgiati, 2002; Ulgiati and Brown, 2002; Lu et al., 2003; Cao and Feng, 2007 ). Here we listed the following three eMergy based indicators used in our study. 3.1.1 Emergy yield ratio ( EYR ) EYR is the ratio of the sum of renewable eMergy ( R ) and nonrenewable eMergy ( N ) and purchased eMergy ( F ) to the purchased emergy ( F ). According to Ulgiati and Brown (2002) , EYR values below 5 denote primary materials, such as cement and steel, and secondary energy resources. Primary energy resources usually have an EYR > 5, and processes with an eMergy yield ratio less than 2 do not contribute to as energy sources and are associated to consumables or manufacturing processes. By comparing EYR values, one can understand the competition ability or economic benefit of a resource. Low values of EYR denote weak competition ability and low economic benefit when a resource is developed. On the contrary, high values of EYR denote strong competition ability and high economic benefit. 3.1.2 Environmental loading ratio ( ELR ) ELR is the ratio of the sum of nonrenewable eMergy ( N ) and purchased eMergy ( F ) to the renewable eMergy ( R ). According to Cao and Feng (2007) , Low values of ELR (nearly 2) indicate low environmental impact or processes having a large area to dilute their total impact. When ELR > 10, there is a high environmental loading, and when 3 < ELR < 10, the impact is considered moderate. For extremely high values of ELR , the nonrenewable inputs and/or the purchased inputs predominate, suggesting that the offer of local renewable inputs is not enough to supply the process demands. Therefore, this index is high for systems with high nonrenewable resources consumption and/or with high emissions. 3.1.3 Sustainability index ( SI ) It is the ratio of the EYR to the ELR . This index reflects the ability of a system in providing desired products or services with a minimum environmental stress and a maximum profit. Cao and Feng (2007) think that when SI < 1, products and processes are not sustainable in the long term. Systems presenting 1 < SI < 5 may have a sustainable contribution to the economy for medium periods, and processes with SI > 5 can be considered sustainable in the long term. But it is incorrect to think that the higher SI , the better the sustainability, because when SI > 10, the system is underdeveloped. 3.2 Improved eMergy based indicators for assessing a sewage treatment ecosystem According to the concept of “sewage treatment ecosystem”, its general eMergy flow system diagram could be drawn, in which emissions impact and waste contribution were also considered (see Fig. 5 ). According to Fig. 5 , an STE's input eMergy equals the sum of eMergy of wastes W (such as sewage inflow), the total eMergy of renewable resources (including R 1 , R 2 , and R 3 from sewage treatment subsystem, the corresponding treated water disposal subsystem and dewatered sludge disposal subsystem, respectively, such as hydroelectricity, air, etc.), the total eMergy of nonrenewable resources (including N 1 , N 2 , and N 3 from the three subsystems respectively, such as chemical reagent, etc.), and the total purchased input eMergy (including F 1 , F 2 , F 3 from the three subsystems, respectively, such as purchasing ground, equipment, technology, information, electricity, commodities and service, etc.). Its output eMergy includes the eMergy of the products and emitted wastes. Here we also considered the emissions’ impacts (including W E1 , W E2 , and W E3 from the three subsystems, respectively), which are described in Section 3.2.1 . 3.2.1 Quantifying the impacts of emissions Emissions from industrial processes can harm the ecosystem, people, and the economy; they may require eMergy to render them harmless ( Yang et al., 2003 ), which can be done by diluting or degrading the emissions to an acceptable concentration or state. 3.2.1.1 Ecological services needed to render emissions harmless This eMergy to absorb impact may be derived from both ecological and economic sources. Many emissions are rendered harmless due to services provided by the ecosystem which dilute or degrade the emissions to an acceptable concentration or state. The eMergy for these ecological services may be determined from knowledge of the concentration and nature of the emissions, and the transformity of the relevant ecological services. We calculated the ecological services for diluting emissions according to the research of Ulgiati and Brown (2002) . Here, we considered the air and water emissions in the sewage treatment process. Although they had been treated before released into environment, the emission concentrations of some of them were still higher than the corresponding environment quality standards. Therefore, the ecological services were needed to dilute their concentration to the acceptable level. The ecological services are environmental self-purification, which includes physical, chemical and biological processes, and it is often the last step of pollutions’ control measures because it is very difficult for all industrial processes to achieve complete zero emissions. Here we considered only the environmental dilution. Ecological services for diluting air pollutants can be counted as follows: firstly, the mass of air required to dilute each emission can be attained according to (1) M = d × W c − M air where M is the mass of dilution air, unit: g; M air is the mass of discharged air from sewage treatment process, unit: g; d is the air density, here it is 1.29E03 g/m 3 ; W is the annual amount of a given air emission from sewage treatment process; c is the acceptable concentration from agreed regulations (see Table 4 ). Then, the energy value of required environmental services is determined, by calculating the kinetic energy of the dilution air, using average value for wind speed in the area (here, the average value for wind speed was 0.70 m/s in a year, Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People's Republic of China, 2006–2009 ). This energy is a measure of the wind energy needed to dilute pollutants. Finally, when multiplied by the wind transformity 1.50E03 seJ/J ( Ulgiati and Brown, 2002 ), it gives a measure of the environmental service that is required, in units of eMergy. Ecological services for diluting water pollutants can be counted as follows: firstly, the mass of water required to dilute each pollutant can be calculated according to (2) M = d × W c − M water where M is the mass of dilution water, g; M water is the mass of water drainage from sewage treatment process, g; d is water density, it is 1.00E06 g/m 3 ; W is the annual amount of a given water pollutant from sewage treatment process, g or unit; and c is the acceptable concentration from agreed regulations (see Table 4 .). Then, the energy needed to dilute water pollutants is determined when the mass of dilution water is multiplied by the average value of physical energy of surface runoff in China. When the energy is multiplied by the transformity of global flowing water in river 2.78E04 seJ/J ( Lan et al., 2002 ), it gives a measure of the environmental service that is required, in units of eMergy. 3.2.1.2 The eMergy loss caused by emissions Some emissions may harm the ecosystem by causing a fish kill, lake eutrophication, etc.; and they also lead to economic loss by harming human health, land occupation, etc. Such effects may be quantified as the eMergy contained in the ecological and economic loss. Many studies have estimated the monetary loss of environmental impact. This may be easily converted to eMergy via the eMergy/money ratio. Quantifying the ecological impact in terms of eMergy requires knowledge about the loss of ecosystem components and self-organization caused by the emissions ( Bakshi, 2000 ). Ecological impact is represented by the Potentially Affected Fraction (PAF) or Potentially Disappeared Fraction (PDF) of species in the affected ecosystem ( Bakshi, 2002 ). This analysis uses ecological models which are currently restricted to the Netherlands or Europe. The output of a LCIA approach such as eco-indicator 99 may be converted to a corresponding exergy loss or eMergy input. Here the ecological losses caused by emissions were not considered due to lacking the corresponding data. We calculated the economic loss caused by emissions according to the references ( Ulgiati et al., 1995; Ukidwe and Bakshi, 2007 ). The loss included air pollutants’ impacts on human health, and land occupation caused by solid wastes. Air emission impact on human health include respiratory disorders, climate change, etc. ( Ukidwe and Bakshi, 2007 ). Disability adjusted life years (DALY) measures the impact on human well being ( Bakshi, 2002 ). This represents the years of life lost and years lived disabled due to the impact of emissions, and it is based on an approach developed by the World Health Organization (WHO). Industrial emissions affect human health in myriad ways. The actual impact depends on the fate of a pollutant in the natural environment and its effect on human well being. The fate itself depends on numerous physico-chemical phenomena such as dispersion, diffusion and atmospheric chemistry. There are several established procedures for calculating the impact of emissions on human health. The approach employed in this analysis represents the impact of several common pollutants on human health in terms of DALY. This is an end-point impact assessment methodology that considers several impact categories including respiratory disorders, climate change, etc. ( Hofstetter, 1998; Goedkoop and Spriensma, 1999 ). Table 6 lists several air pollutants considered in this work, the impact categories they belong to and corresponding DALY values per gram of emission. Ukidwe and Bakshi (2004) discussed the approach for converting DALYs to ecological cumulative exergy consumption (ECEC). Relationship between DALY and ECEC is linear, and 1 DALY/day of human health impact corresponds to 9.35E13 seJ/day of impact in ECEC terms. Furthermore, conversion of DALY into ECEC is necessary only if it is desired to have a single numeraire for comparing diverse flows of ecosystem goods and services, human resources and emissions and their impact on human health. ECEC is an extension of industrial cumulative exergy consumption to include ecosystems, and it becomes equivalent to eMergy if the analysis boundary, allocation approach, and method for combining global energy inputs are identical ( Hau and Bakshi, 2004 ). Then we can count the eMergy value of emission impacts on human health according to ECEC values of emissions. This study just considered the four air pollutants indicated in Table 5 . Other pollutants were not considered. Land occupation can measure discharged solid waste impacts on the environment. According to the reference ( Wang et al., 2006a,b ), 2.85 × 10 4 tons industrial solid wastes approximately occupy 1 ha land. According to the reference ( Odum, 2000 ), an average annual eMergy value of land is obtained from the average rate of erosion and replacement, and the transformity of land area sustained is 1.05E15 seJ/ha. Thus the eMergy loss can be attained using the total occupied land area multiplied by the transformity. 3.2.2 Improved eMergy based indicators for assessing an STE Then we can construct the following improved eMergy based indicators for assessing an STE. (1) EYR : it is Emergy yield ratio of an STE. This indicator can be expressed as follow: (3) E Y R = ( W + R + N + F ) F Here, W : emergy of wastes input, such as sewage inflow; R = R 1 + R 2 + R 3 ; N = N 1 + N 2 + N 3 ; F = F 1 + F 2 + F 3 . Unit: seJ/a. (2) ELR : it is environmental loading ratio of an STE. Since the main goal of an STE is to remove or reduce environmental pressure, how will the environmental pressure change after the STE's implement compared with before? Therefore, we should consider the emissions’ impacts from the STE and integrate it into ELR . The improved EYR can be expressed as follow: (4) E L R = ( N + F + W E ) R Here, W E : emissions’ impacts, W E = EL + ES. EL: eMergy loss caused by emissions; ES: ecological services needed to dilute air and water pollutants to an acceptable level. Unit: seJ/a. (3) SI : it is ASUSTAINABILITY index of an STE, defined as the ratio of EYR to ELR , and it reflects the relative sustainability of sewage treatment ecosystem. This indicator can be expressed as follow: (5) S I = E Y R E L R The eMergy system diagrams of scenarios 1 and 2 are shown in Figs. 6 and 7 , and the two scenarios’ eMergy analysis tables are shown in Tables 6 and 7 . 4 Results and analysis 4.1 Emissions’ impacts Emission impacts are shown in Table 8 . For scenario 1, the value of emission impacts was 2.40E20 seJ/a, which mainly came from ecological services (99.99%), next came from eMergy loss (0.01%). And most of ecological services came from water environment service needed to dilute water pollutants, especially diluting TN. For scenario 2, the value of emission impacts was 2.38E16 seJ/a, which mainly came from eMergy loss (97.94%), next came from ecological services (2.06%). And those impacts of scenario 2 were all caused by air pollutants. Therefore, the emission impacts are greatly reduced after the treated water and dewatered sludge being reused. However, the air emission impacts should be further emphasized for scenario 2. 4.2 Emergy flows The two scenarios’ eMergy flows are shown in Table 9 . The ratios of W , R , N and F to the total input eMergy for each scenario are shown in Table 10 . For scenario 1, it was found out that more than 96% of input eMergy came from wastes input, about 1.4% came from renewable inputs, about 0.1% came from nonrenewable inputs, and about 2.4% came from purchased inputs. For scenario 2, more than 93.3% of input eMergy came from wastes input, about 2.3% came from renewable inputs, about 0.2% came from nonrenewable inputs, and about 4.2% came from purchased inputs. Therefore, nonrenewable and renewable input eMergy was much less than wastes input eMergy in the total input eMergy for the two scenarios, which was consistent with the research of Vassallo et al. (2009) . 4.3 Emergy based indicators The values of the traditional and improved eMergy based indicators for the two scenarios were calculated, respectively and shown in Table 11 . According to the results of the traditional eMergy based indicators, the value of EYR for scenario 2 was decreased by 2.57%, the value of ELR for scenario 2 was increased by 5.62%, and the value of SI for scenario 2 was decreased by 7.76%, compared with scenario 1; and this means that scenario 2 has weaker competitive ability and higher environmental stress than scenario 1 does. Therefore, the sustainability of scenario 2 is lower than that of scenario 1. According to the improved based indicators’ results, the value of EYR for scenario 2 was decreased by 42.15%, the value of ELR for scenario 2 was decreased by 97.39%, and the value of SI for scenario 2 was increased by 95.95%, compared with scenario 1; therefore, scenario 2 has weaker competitive ability but much lower environmental stress than scenario 2. As a result, scenario 2 is still more sustainable than scenario 1. In scenario 2, the values of the three subsystems’ improved eMergy based indices were shown in Table 12 . It was found that the value of EYR of the reclaimed water reuse subsystem was the biggest, next came from the sewage treatment subsystem, and the value of EYR of the aerobic compost production subsystem was the smallest; the value of ELR of the sewage treatment subsystem was the biggest, next came from the reclaimed water reuse subsystem, and the value of ELR of the aerobic compost production subsystem was the smallest; the value of SI of the aerobic compost production subsystem was the biggest, next came from the reclaimed water reuse subsystem, and the value of SI of the sewage treatment subsystem was the smallest. Therefore, the reclaimed water reuse subsystem has the strongest competition, the sewage treatment subsystem has the greatest pressure on environment, and the aerobic compost production subsystem is the most sustainable among the three subsystems. 5 Discussion In this study emissions’ impacts were quantified in the term of eMergy, and they were integrated into improved eMergy based indicators. The differences between the traditional indicators and the improved ones lie in the former ignoring emissions’ impacts and wastes input's contribution. The results from the case study show that the constructed STE has predominant environmental performance although its economic performance is somewhat weaker than the traditional end-of-pipe treatment here. The case is only used to validate the proposed indicators, and the results may be different in other occasions. In addition, emissions from the reclaimed water reuse subsystem and the aerobic compost production subsystem were not considered for lacking the available data, maybe the environmental load was underestimated more or less. These do not affect the proposed indicators’ effectiveness. The approach proposed not only can be used to analyze alternative scenarios and each subsystem in one wastewater treatment process, but also offers a framework for assessing how to combine these different procedures into a complementary and comprehensive model of analysis. This approach can consider and compare a global environmental strategy that might include the use of different sewage treatment ecosystems composed of different sewage treatment crafts and treated water disposal crafts and sewage sludge disposal crafts, since it is able to account for all of the resources used in any phase and in the total process of the system and locate the correct eMergy use in accordance with the benefit obtained. In the light of the required creative process, it must be underscored that the described sewage management scenarios represent a gradual technological improvement which does not solve the problem completely (For example, from the viewpoint of lifecycle, there are some environmental impacts when aerobic compost is applied for agricultural production, which is out of the scope of this paper.), but this paper provides better knowledge about it. Even if other better scenarios could gradually approach the upper levels by means of technological improvement and enhancing material and energy efficiency, there is a level where technology seems unable to provide the basis for further steps. If we remain trapped within a purely technological improvement strategy, “zero wastewater/zero emissions” may be an unreachable target. Thus, in order to solve the issue of wastewater treatment, not only we should rely on building new technologically advanced treatment plants, but also we should implement wastewater prevention policies, based on the higher levels of the pyramid (“Recycle” and “Reuse”), as well as on redesigning our production and consumption patterns towards the ideal condition of wastewater prevention, wastewater reuse. 6 Conclusion This paper constructed a sewage treatment ecosystem, including a sewage treatment system and its treated water disposal system and dewatered sludge disposal system. Through considering the economic and environmental impacts of wastes treatment and disposal, emissions’ impacts, and wastes input’ s contribution, this paper constructed the improved eMergy based indicators for evaluating the sustainability of the holistic system. With EYR and ELR and SI , it is demonstrated how it is possible to analyze the economic benefit, environmental pressure, and sustainability of different sewage treatment ecosystems. The results from the case study show that the improved eMergy based indicators are more rigorous than the traditional ones; wastes reuse can improve the environmental performance of the STE greatly while this somewhat weakens the sewage treatment process’ economic performance, but its sustainability is still greatly enhanced. In order to improve the economic and environmental performance of an STE, the sewage treatment subsystem should be firstly emphasized, including: controlling investment, such as strengthening research and evaluation of project feasibility, technology innovation, design and construction optimization, controlling manufacturing cost during engineering implementation, final accounts and auditing of completed project, etc.; reducing operating cost, such as norm management of electrical energy consumption, perfecting gauge work and management of related all electrical equipments and circuits, strengthening daily management of all king of materials, etc. Then the reclaimed water reuse system should be also improved, such as deciding on rational goals of reclaimed water reuse according to the local conditions, choosing the proper craft of reclaimed water reuse, determining reasonable price of the reclaimed water, etc. Of course, the related laws and regulations should be enacted and/or perfected, such as confirming the position of reclaimed water and sludge reuse, making the related technical standards, etc., besides the corresponding mature technologies. In addition, air emissions’ impacts from wastewater treatment processes should be emphasized in future. The improved eMergy based indicators can form a set of useful tools to compare the comprehensive performances of different sewage treatment processes for decision-making and optimizing the whole process. RHxXEipf.title: Determination of the stable carbon isotopic compositions of 2-methyltetrols in ambient aerosols from the Changbai Mountains.
RHxXEipf.abstract: Isoprene is one of the most important non-methane hydrocarbons (NMHCs) in the troposphere: it is a significant precursor of O(3) and it affects the oxidative state of the atmosphere. The diastereoisomeric 2-methyltetrols, 2-methylthreitol and 2-methylerythritol, are marker compounds of the photooxidation products of atmospheric isoprene. In order to obtain valuable information on the delta(13)C value of isoprene in the atmosphere, the stable carbon isotopic compositions of the 2-methyltetrols in ambient aerosols were investigated. The 2-methyltetrols were extracted from filter samples and derivatized with methylboronic acid, and the delta(13)C values of the methylboronate derivatives were determined by gas chromatography/combustion/isotope ratio mass spectrometry (GC/C/IRMS). The delta(13)C values of the 2-methyltetrols were then calculated through a simple mass balance equation between the 2-methyltetrols, methylboronic acid and the methylboronates. The delta(13)C values of the 2-methyltetrols in aerosol samples collected at the Changbai Mountain Nature Reserves in eastern China were found to be -24.66 +/- 0.90 per thousand and -24.53 +/- 1.08 per thousand for 2-methylerythritol and 2-methylthreitol, respectively. Based on the measured isotopic composition of the 2-methyltetrols, the average delta(13)C value of atmospheric isoprene is inferred to be close to or slightly heavier than -24.66 per thousand at the collection site during the sampling period.
RHxXEipf.venue: Rapid communications in mass spectrometry : RCM

Wo2VaeFX.title: Nitrogen removal from livestock and poultry breeding wastewaters using a novel sequencing batch biofilm reactor.
Wo2VaeFX.abstract: A study was conducted regarding the biological nitrogen removal from the livestock and poultry breeding wastewater (LPBWs) using a novel sequencing batch biofilm reactor (SBBR). Nitrogen removal process was studied under three aeration strategies/modes, referred to as MODE 1, 2, and 3. The results showed that MODE 2 (one operation period: instant fill of LPBWs, 3.0 h aeration, 1.5 h non-aeration, 1.5 h aeration, 1.0 h non-aeration and rapid drain of treated LPBWs) performed the best in nitrogen removal. Under MODE 2, the removal efficiencies were as high as 96.1 and 92.1% for NH₃-N and TN, respectively. Simultaneous nitrification and denitrification (SND), as well as shortcut nitrification and denitrification are likely to be the two main mechanisms for the nitrogen removal in this study. Nitrifying bacteria were not inhibited by heterotrophic bacteria with C/N ratios ranging from 18.1 to 21.4 and DO concentration of 2.0 mg/l. Alternation between aeration and non-aeration played an important role in NO₂⁻ accumulation.

zNghM69d.title: Modeling the relationship between energy consumption and economy development in China
zNghM69d.abstract: Highlights ► Decomposed total energy consumption in three parts, branch of material produces, branch of the immaterial production, and households. ► Energy consumed by branch of material produces considered the economic scale and construction. ► Energy consumed by immaterial production was first referred in this article. ► The relationship between energy consumed by household and GDP fits the invert-S curve, which is first referred too.

tcmmtzOd.title: Emergy evaluation of the impact of waste exchanges on the sustainability of industrial systems
tcmmtzOd.abstract: Emergy evaluation provided global performance indicators that were used to assess the impact of waste exchanges on the sustainability of a sulfuric acid production system (SAPS) and a titanium dioxide production system (TDPS) in Pan-zhi-hua City, China. Impact of emissions was quantified in terms of emergy and integrated into the classic emergy-based indicators. Results show that waste exchanges improve the sustainability of the two systems, although the SAPS benefits more from the waste exchanges than the TDPS from an economic perspective however, the impact of emissions reduces their sustainability to some degree. This study creates awareness and brings new insight to the gains achieved with resource recovery from waste in the interrelated industrial systems, which is derived from the mutualism relationship existing in natural ecosystems. Finally, this paper puts forward some corresponding suggestions.
